BOOK FOURTH.</br>On the dark cliffs that skirt Menevia's bay,</br>What chief pursues his solitary way!</br>Bold is his mien; his wide emblazon'd shield</br>Bears the deep marks of many a well-fought field:</br>O'er his bright helm high waves the sable crest,</br>And anxious care sits on his brow imprest!

'Tis Lancelot—in arms of high renown,</br>The brave defender of the British crown;</br>By ruthless foes sore prest, who unsubdued,</br>Thro' Hengist's camp his course of havoc hew'd</br>At night's still hour, when his deluded foes</br>Were sunk in revelry, or dead repose.

Th' ensuing morn, clouds piled on clouds arise,</br>Black in the west; loud-echoing through the skies</br>Shrieks the wild wind; descends th' impetuous rain,</br>And the swoll'n stream foams through the ravag'd plain.

A narrow bridge across the current lay;</br>O'er that the warriors urge their rapid way,</br>Brave Lancelot the last; whilst in the rear</br>Borne on their trampling steeds the foes draw near.</br>In twain, his heroes aid, the bridge he rends;</br>Down the rude stream the floating mass descends:</br>Nor dare the foes, so turbulent its course,</br>Mid the wild eddies plunge their foaming horse.</br>Indignant fury in their bosom reigns;</br>The scalding tear of baffled rage disdains</br>The glowing cheek.  Ye rescued warriors!  raise</br>To heaven the voice of gratitude and praise.</br>Had fearless Hengist led the hostile train,</br>Opposing torrents would have raged in vain,</br>Then had he sunk beneath the whelming tide,</br>Or British blood the waves with crimson dyed.

But he, the warriors pent in walls disdain'd;</br>New foes he sought, and new renown obtain'd.</br>With all his knights, and half the Saxon host,</br>He burst in terror on Albania's coast.</br>Her sons in vain his matchIess force withstood;</br>Death mark'd his way, his path was traced in blood.</br>Returning now with conquest crown'd, he hears</br>Th' unwelcome news, and swift revenge prepares.</br>The weird sisters check his swelling ire,</br>And bid their champion to the dome retire,</br>Which rear'd by magic, fenc'd by potent charms,</br>Could mock, they proudly deem'd, the world in arms.

By rapid march the Britons render vain</br>Their foes pursuit, and Cambria's confines gain.</br>Its generous sons their friendly arms assume;</br>On various summits war's collected gloom,</br>Like winter's hovering mist, impending lours,</br>And threats destruction to the hostile powers.

As thus their watch th' appointed warriors keep,</br>Their leader hastens t'ward the billowy deep:</br>By Merlin warn'd, that thro' the narrow main</br>The prince approach'd with his auxiliar train.</br>Alas!  not then to Britain's sage was known</br>That danger's cloud hung dark o'er Uther's son.

As bends the chief his long-expecting eyes,</br>Like scatter'd mists on ocean's verge arise</br>The wish'd-for sails; that soon in swelling pride</br>And cloth'd with brightness o'er the billows glide;</br>And anchor'd in Menevia's crouded bay,</br>A leafless forest to his view display.

First o'er the strand th' Armoric leader prest,</br>Known by his sun-bright helm, and gorgeous crest,</br>The far fam'd Indian bird; it struck the view</br>With eyes of jet, and neck of purple hue,</br>While its gay train with gems and gold inlaid,</br>A splendid ring of mingled light display'd;</br>The high-priz'd gift of Uther's mighty son,</br>In combat from a Paynim monarch won;</br>Born on the banks where sacred Ganges pours</br>O'er gold-besprinkled sands his lucid stores.</br>Where ripen'd by the genial blaze of day</br>Rich gems their emulative  beams display.</br>Where musky sweets from flower-deck'd groves exhale;</br>And double harvests load the fertile vale.
Known was the Briton by his silver shield:</br>A callow eagle sculptur'd on the field,</br>To Hope's bright image bent his eager eyes,</br>Who rear'd her arm aloft, and pointed to the skies.

The heroes, who on Asia's burning soil</br>Had mutual dangers shar'd, and mutual toil,</br>Meet with that joy the brave alone can know,</br>When friendship's beams in kindred bosoms glow:</br>Summon'd again the shock of arms to dare,</br>And run together glory's bright career.
Next Clodion came; the glittering helm behind,</br>His crimson plumes flew streaming on the wind.</br>As dusky vapours ting'd with sanguine hue</br>The glowing comet's rapid course pursue.

Ierne's gallant chiefs, with spurs of speed,</br>Maronan, Conal, Adamar succeed.</br>Fiacha next, who ruled th' Emanian land,</br>Himself a host, precedes his martial band.</br>Beneath his shaggy brow his eye-balls glare,</br>Redundant waves around his sable hair,</br>Nor lance he wields, nor bounding steed bestrides,</br>But in his matchless strength, his iron mace confides.

Last, slowly-moving o'er the strand appears</br>(Sad, silent, trailing their inverted spears)</br>The knightly train, who long from shore to shore</br>Had rang'd with Britain's prince thro' ocean's roar.</br>Who, till he plung'd beneath the whelming tide,</br>Had mock'd at woe, and fortune's power defied.</br>Now grief sate heavy on each manly breast,</br>And pale despondence every brow confest.

Like rocks down whose cold sides the waters flow,</br>Th' auxiliar leaders stand in silent woe:</br>But grief superior, Lancelot, to feel</br>Was thine, and thine thy anguish to conceal.</br>For now from troop to troop the tidings ran,</br>And frequent thus th' inferior herd began.

"Bootless in idle wars to waste our blood:</br>The hero sunk beneath the whelming flood,</br>For whom alone we vow'd our arms to wield,</br>And brave the terrors of th' embattled field.</br>Fierce is the foe, but open lies the main;</br>For doubtful honour let us safety gain!"

"Can cold dismay, thus Britain's knight addrest</br>The warriors, quench the fire in valour's breast!</br>Leaders of battle!  low the mighty lies,</br>But blood, not tears, must grace his obsequies.</br>Like wave on wave impell'd in yonder bay,</br>The race of man successive rolls away:</br>Unnoted pass the feeble, but the brave</br>Survive to glory, and defy the grave.</br>If such was Arthur, such your generous aim,</br>Avenge him, warriors; — emulate his fame!</br>But if thro' terror vain those tears are shed,</br>Disgraceful to yourselves, and of the dead</br>Unworthy: — know, tho' you your aid deny,</br>The sons of Britain shall the combat try.</br>Their country's wrongs, their Arthur's sacred shade,</br>Will nerve each arm, and edge th' avenging blade.</br>And when our death, or conquest reach your ear,</br>For only death, or conquest now is dear,</br>Then, warriors, touch'd with generous shame too late,</br>Our fame you'll envy, or lament our fate."

"Your fate to mourn, or at your fame repine,</br>Th' Armoric king return'd; be never mine!</br>Not more to Lancelot, than Hoel dear,</br>Was Uther's son — with thee I lift the spear:</br>Resolv'd alike in glory's path to tread;</br>Resolv'd to perish, or avenge the dead."

With brow contracted stern Fiacha cries,</br>"Thou wrong'st us, Briton, by the vain surmise,</br>Sooner the feeble arm of man shall tear</br>Yon self-suspended lamp that fires the air</br>From his ethereal arch, than fears controul</br>Our mind, or change the purport of our soul.</br>And sure we trust, that spark of heavenly flame</br>Shall quickly animate a nobler frame.</br>Till, by degrees from mortal dross refin'd,</br>It leaves the body's cumb'rous load behind.</br>To conquest lead — or death!  our hearts beat high,</br>To gain a nearer prospect of the sky."

Like him, each gallant leader undismay'd,</br>On his broad buckler clash'd the glittering blade,</br>And loud exclaim'd:  "While these our arms can wield,</br>We scorn to shun the dangers of the field."</br>"Brothers in war, whom honor's bands unite!</br>Exulting thus rejoin'd the British knight,</br>Accept my heartfelt thanks, the grateful praise,</br>A glowing bosom to your virtue pays.</br>Dwells there in all these bands a soul so mean,</br>That shrinks in terror from th' impending scene,</br>Forth let the dastard stand — there lies the main,</br>And free the way: — shall we his flight restrain?</br>In some lone cavern let him hide his shame,</br>Not share with honor's sons the meed of fame."

His words with loud acclaim the valiant hear;</br>The coward feels not, or conceals his fear.</br>And now the lofty voice of war resounds</br>From Sabrine's, banks to Gwineth's rocky bounds.</br>Whilst the pale mother to her panting breast</br>The infant clasps, with tender fears opprest,</br>The father calls to arms:  from mountains hoar,</br>Dark woods and winding dells the heroes pour.</br>To guard the craggy summits they disdain;</br>The storm of war descends, and echoes thro' the plain.

Beneath their steel-clad chiefs in bright array,</br>The ranks of battle urge their rapid way.</br>As when the sun beams gild th' autumnal sky,</br>And blasts inconstant o'er the valley fly,</br>With varied light the waving grass is crown'd,</br>And quick, successive, splendor floats around.

In Carlile's lofty hall, in festive state,</br>The Dacian monarch mid his heroes sate.</br>In Hengist's absence, such the king's commands,</br>Th' appointed leader of the Northern bands.</br>Ill-brook'd by Hacon, grown in combats grey,</br>Norway's dread lord, beneath whose iron sway</br>E'en distant Thule groan'd, and lands unknown</br>To fame, that stretch beneath the frigid zone.

Sullen and stern he marks the genial rites;</br>The music charms not, nor the feast delights.</br>Sweno in silent grief his father view'd,</br>A generous youth with milder thoughts endued;</br>And lovely as the rosy morn that streams</br>Thro' vernal showers its joy-diffusing beams:</br>Whose voice when untam'd passions sway'd his soul,</br>Alone could sooth his woes, or rage controul.

The goblet circles; the resounding lyre,</br>And lofty strain heroic thoughts inspire.</br>Some vaunt their high exploits in former wars;</br>Some shew their batter'd shields, and deep-trench'd scars:</br>In brutal riot some the hours employ,</br>And all is dissonance, and barbarous joy.

Sudden, dark clouds the rafter'd dome o'ercast;</br>Upwards they turn their anxious eyes aghast:</br>And thro' the quick disparting shades behold</br>Dread Odin, seated on his throne of gold.</br>Black vapors, such as clothe the wintry night,</br>His foot-stool form'd; a meteor's vivid light</br>His brows encircled:  radiant arms he wore,</br>And shook his flaming lance distain'd with gore.</br>Loud as when thunder roars he silence broke—</br>The vast dome trembled as the phantom spoke.

"Offspring of heroes!  fam'd in fields of fight,</br>Who sport in danger, and in death delight,</br>Does this become you, sons of battle!  say,</br>To wear in shameful sloth the hours away?</br>Is this a time to feast in bower or hall,</br>When foes advancing to the combat call?</br>The host you deem'd beneath the roaring main</br>O'erwhelm'd, defies you to the listed plain.</br>The cloud of war on Cambria's height impends</br>No more, but darkly-lowering hither bends.</br>Awake, arise, and in your might confide!</br>Rush on, and let destruction be your guide!</br>Think on your father's fame, your own renown,</br>My favour, who with joys perpetual  crown</br>The chiefs, who boldly in the combat fall,</br>And guide their spirits to my lofty hall,</br>O'er arch'd with golden shields, whose dazzling blaze</br>Exceeds the mid-day sun's  unclouded rays.</br>There shall each hero share, a welcome guest,</br>The foaming goblet, and perpetual feast.</br>Again their souls with martial fire shall burn,</br>And host conflicting adverse host o'erturn:</br>While bright Valkeries, blue-eyed nymphs shall crown</br>With plausive smiles their actions of renown.</br>Be conquest yours, and fame's unfading wreath,</br>Or, more than victory, a glorious death!"

This said, the dark'ning cloud, the meteor's glare,</br>And stately form dissolves, and melts in air.</br>"Be all our warriors summon'd to the field!"</br>Cried Valdemar, and struck his echoing shield:</br>"On every height your banners wide unfold!</br>At morn we march; and let the sun behold,</br>As in the purpled East he rises bright,</br>Our arms of splendor emulate his light!"

"Tho' Valdemar's proud banners brave the skies,</br>Beneath his sway we march not; Hacon cries.</br>Know, tho' a God commands, the soul is free,</br>To mortal power we scorn to bend the knee,</br>Or yield subjection — no, were Hengist here,</br>Whose actions I admire, and fame revere,</br>Thus had I spoke:  nor deem my words, O king!</br>From mean distrust, or canker'd envy spring.</br>To lead the Danes, the Saxon bands, be thine;</br>So Hengist will'd, but Norway's sons are mine.</br>Resolv'd as brave allies your cause to own,</br>And no superior but their king alone."

Cerdic and Ida, Saxons far renown'd,</br>Upstarting at the word, indignant frown'd.</br>In fiercer wrath the Dacian chieftains rise;</br>Biorno, Grimal, roll their silent eyes,</br>As secretly they grasp the ready blade,</br>On their lov'd lord.  He, doubtful, long survey'd</br>His haughty rival; but reflection quell'd</br>The vengeful thoughts that in his bosom swell'd.

"If Hacon at our rule," he cried, "repine,</br>Be his apart to lead Norwegia's line.</br>Brave are thy warriors, and a foe draws nigh,</br>Who soon their prowess will severely try.</br>Then, generous emulation be our aim,</br>Best to deserve, and win the meed of fame!"

Performing barbarous rites, a gloomy band,</br>The priests all night before their altars stand.</br>Meanwhile, in cadence low, or choral chime,</br>The herds alternate wake the Runic rhyme,</br>With mystic import fraught:  but chief to thee</br>Swells the full peal of mingled harmony,</br>Dread god of battle!  so they fondly deem,</br>Bewilder'd, lost in error's fatal dream.</br>Now, a vain shadow, and an empty name,</br>Is he, who foremost trod the fields of fame.</br>Not his the form that struck their wond'ring sight,</br>Urda that form assum'd thro' magic sleight.</br>And whilst their rugged altars stream with gore,</br>And their wild cries the hapless victims pour;</br>Whilst lost in trance extatic seems the seer,</br>Whose words as heaven's high dictates they revere,</br>Urda his soul with high-wrought frenzy fires,</br>And fate's ambiguous oracles inspires.

"Sons of the North!  ignoble fear despise;</br>Propitious smiles the god who rules the skies:</br>And, as the wild winds, mingling in their course,</br>O'erturn the forest with united force;</br>Your strength united shall dismay the foe;</br>And lay the towering ranks of battle low.</br>Unwonted fear shall seize the hostile band,</br>And the pois'd lance drop from the valiant hand.</br>Unless your heroes first in arms renown'd,</br>Plant in each other's breast the deadly wound;</br>Arthur shall ne'er the British throne ascend,</br>But all his dream of pride in ruin end."
He ceas'd; convulsions shook his lab'ring frame,</br>And his red eye-balls gleam'd with living flame;</br>Then, as th' inspiring fiend forsook his breast,</br>He sunk unconscious in the arms of rest.

With loud acclaim the priests and minstrel train,</br>The presage hail, and pour the suppliant strain.</br>"Hear, mighty father of thy battle!  hear,</br>Lift thy broad buckler, shake the flashing spear!</br>With wrath's dark cloud thy aweful brows invest,</br>And scatter terror from thy nodding crest!</br>The foes shall sink beneath the dreadful sight,</br>And ghastly horror seize them in the fight."

Faint streaks of light shoot thro' the eastern skies,</br>And wrapt in mist the distant mountains rise.</br>As round their hollow oak bees swarming play,</br>When the sun downward shoots his fervid ray,</br>Athwart, direct, along the echoing plain</br>In wild confusion pour the martial train;</br>Till rang'd in order by their leader's care,</br>The clarion sounds, and onward rolls the war.
In two black columns their destructive way</br>They bend; like clouds in summer's sultry day;</br>Each in his womb the lurking thunder hides,</br>And waving lightnings edge their sable sides.

In Nubia's desarts, by th' attractive beam</br>Of heaven exhal'd, as poisonous vapours steam,</br>Ascend the skies, and from their flagging wings</br>Shake pestilence, and death's pernicious stings;</br>Such havoc marks their course; by sword, by fire,</br>The land lies waste, and man and beast expire.

Where Deva's streams the Cestrian plains divide,</br>Hacon and Denmark's lord, on either side,</br>High-towering in their battle's front, pursu'd</br>Their rapid way:  at length the warriors view'd</br>The distant heights in clouds of dust array'd,</br>And arms faint gleaming thro' the rolling shade.

"Behold," fierce Hacon cried, "behold our foes!"</br>(Whilst in his soul the martial transport rose)</br>"To rage unbounded give the loosen'd rein!</br>Banquet your hungry falchions on the slain!</br>Impel, as meteors cleave the vault of night,</br>A radiant shower!  your shafts' destructive flight!</br>In British blood the vengeful spear embrue,</br>And give the sacrifice to Odin due!"

Fired by their monarch's words, his daring train</br>Advanc'd impetuous o'er the sounding plain.</br>As Valdemar their rapid march beheld,</br>Athwart the current swiftly he impell'd</br>His bounding steed; the furious king addrest,</br>And thus the ardour of his soul represt.

"If terror-struck yon warriors shun'd the fight,</br>It then were fit to urge their shameful flight;</br>But lo!  defiance stern their battle wears:</br>Still, as of old, amid the shock of spears,</br>On highest deeds resolv'd is Britain's train,</br>To die or conquer — fame to give or gain.</br>Then, let us wait till morn the skies illume,</br>To prove our matchless force, and feel their doom.</br>For see, the sun descending from his height,</br>Discloses many a gulf of dazzling light</br>Thro' black, obstructing clouds that westward rise;</br>And now in sanguine radiance cloaths the skies.</br>A dreadful omen of the coming day</br>To Britain's race.  Soon o'er their destin'd prey</br>The birds of heaven shall shake their sounding wings,</br>Exulting — the gaunt wolf shall feast on kings.</br>'Tis ours, let dastards veil their acts in night,</br>To claim the sun a witness to our might."
Hacon assents:  heaven's setting splendors gild</br>The snow-white tents. — Thus scatter'd o'er the field,</br>Appears the fleecy flock at even tide,</br>Recumbent by the fountain's rushy side.
Not thrice an arrow's flight across the plain</br>Approach the vanguard of the hostile train.</br>Their cornets sound; their fiery coursers neigh,</br>And high in air their waving banners play.
